comments.commentBody:
...dossiers, prepared under the Bush administration,....

I could read no more. No way I could look at these mens/boys faces and let the most corrupt presidency I have lived through, possibly lie to me again.

Despite President Obama's pledge to close the Gitmo facility, a craven congress voted to keep it open. Its so easy to play the fear card. Most men held there did not belong there--thats been shown clearly enough. And even those that did suffered inappropriately cruel and absurd treatment that hurts us as a nation -- as does our widespread collusion with dictators and intelligence services in Libya and Syria to do our dirty work, ie torture often based on false information.

If the American Public, having been brainwashed by Fox and by 24, and if 60 percent of US young people, now think they support torture, then we have failed to bring up a nation worthy of the name the Land of the Free.

It would have been better to have a non military trial as we did for the 1994 WTC plot--that worked just fine. But instead we have to hide the evidence collected through torture. Instead we build more of the police state. We are obsessed with peace through force and neglectful of education and justice that must be the foundation of lasting peace.

By demonizing these gitmo guys and making them into powerful opponents in the public mind, which loves a fallguy, which believes in monsters under the bed, we construct a fictitious security and fail to modify our foreign policies that should be modified. We build more bases in the Middle East and fail to counter Israeli trumphalism. No wonder there is resentment but thank God the resentment is now focused on the local dictators our proxies!

Our leaders--religious leaders, community leaders, politicians-- bear the moral responsbility to insist in the all too powerful media that just because revenge feels sweet does not make it right. This sort of amoral sweetness leads to diabetic shock on a massive scale. I am not sure if the soul of this nation is alive... or dead.
Capital punishment deters the person executed; he will not murder again.
His mother should get the death penalty for creating him and for driving the getaway car. http://noonmeasurec.blogspot.com/

There's a reason why every other Western power--and many non-Western ones, including Russia--have abandoned the death penalty: the very notion that the protection of human dignity and justice, which are the paramount obligations of the state, can be harmonized with such an insidious and barbaric institution is patently absurd. Unfortunately, in its zeal to enforce a warped, allegedly "Christian" concept of vengeance, the American body politic has aligned this country with such brutal dictatorships and fundamentalist oligarchies such as Iran, China, and Saudi Arabia, which denigrates and cheapens us as a people. I am heartened that several states have abandoned the death penalty in the last several years; however, its continued existence provides a great challenge to my pride in being American.

"So when I thought about his soul...., I came to believe a death sentence for DiMeo would have been a gift."

Mr. Donnelly, I am not sure what the point of your article is: to make us think about capital punishment in general, or make us think about forgiveness in general, or make us think about the particular circumstances of your family's horrible loss, or simply to express your anguish, or to do all of the above.

but having had family members killed by a drunk driver, i would like to advise you not to waste your time considering the warped soul or reasons of the transgressor, but your own. let Mr. DiMeo languish in prison; the justice system worked well enough in this case. whether a death sentence would have been a "gift" or not for Mr. DiMeo, only he can decide. but you must move on and live your life as your brother and his wife would have wanted.

I have different reasons than Mr. Donnelly for preferring life sentences without parole for heinous crimes, though I don't begrudge him for his feelings of vengeance, given the circumstances.

First, cost. A death penalty trial and subsequent appeals costs significantly more than keeping a person in prison for life, and has put a huge financial strain on smaller communities in the past.

Second, you can't raise an innocent man from the grave, and as the Innocence Project has shown, a large number of innocent people are in prison today, and as solid evidence of their innocence becomes available, they deserve to be set free.

I do support life sentences without parole, because too many murderers that have been paroled have gone on to kill again.

Doh! Give me a break! Eliminate holds, and allow a simple majority to approve nominees. No president should have a blank slate to appoint administration posts, but the present system is a recipe for vindictiveness.

The congress is going to need a plumbers's " pipe snake " to unclogg their agenda. Their congressional work schedule consists of, 2wks on and a week off. And at that rate , not much of the "people's work "  gets done. But they're still getting paid and enjoying that wonderful federally funded healthcare !!
Hooray for marxists.  More marxist appointees, just what we need form the one.  See you on 2012.

This is a reminder of just how dysfunctional Congress has become. Their dysfunction is dysfunctional! Because they can't reform their own rules, they are willing to give up yet more power to the executive branch.

And reform in the case of nominees would be relatively simple if you did not think like a Congressman. (1) Eliminate fake filibusters - require that someone actually stand up and talk. (2) Eliminate anonymous holds. (3) Require a simple majority to bring a confirmation up for vote.

I saw this movie and thoroughly enjoyed it !! The character Harry is definitely not a drip. The author sees him as judgemental while I like to see him as someone with great moral values. Values that are missing in this day and age. Definitely worth watching.

post 6 -- There are two issues one global warming causing droght and other part of natural variation. The original posting says the precipitation is presenting an increasing trend since 1895. The post 6 quotes a movement of equitorial rain band northward in the last 1300. These do not match. Unusual events are occurring all over the globe, some cases the extreme was noted in the past in some other cases in recent years. By careful study of the long term precipitation series will provide a clue. It does not mean we should not control transportation based air pollution and its creation of ground level ozone, which is health hazard gas. Whether this influences the precipitation or not it influences the health and thus need controlling of such gases in the atmosphere air. In vie of this only recently UNEP and WMO proposed a policy change on climate change as climate change stopgap which involves controlling ground level ozone and shoot.

Dr. S. Jeevananda Reddy

Re #13: "The Saudis want to sell as much oil as they possibly can."

I doubt that this is true. (If it is, they're being very silly.) If they're intelligent, what they want is to make as much money from selling oil as they can. So which makes more money: producing 9 million barrels a day and selling it at $25/bbl, or producing 7 million barrels and selling it at $125/bbl?

It's gratifying to see nature hitting hard at the hard-core of the American "denialism".
So governor Perry, more gas guzzlers in Texas - to return nature's favors with "economic upsurge", and more prayers (a "XXI-century" way of facing reality), would surely help.
Iraqi Oil production has been steadily rising.
We cannot live without clean water. Why doesn't Mr Man want to disclose chemicals used unless they are harmful.
Now the most rare thing in human is humanity.
While your concern is laudable, it mainly serves to distract from a more central issue. Who finances this terrorism? And how do they continue to avoid your investigative scrutiny?

I was actually lucky enough to attend the SXSW presentation that Ramona Pringle gave, that is mentioned here. One of the first things she said in her talk was that she isn't suggesting that WoW is the new Match.com. She says that on her website, too. The two couples in this article may have met in the game, but her work is much more about what we can learn from the games and it can apply not just to romance but to friendships, partnerships, working teams, etc. As a woman who has a rich life and a successful career and has been gaming for over 5 years (since an ex got me into it!!) I think it is AWESOME to see WoW in the fashion section of the NY Times. It's a new era when gamers are in the style section and I think it's great. Kudos to Ms. Rosenblum and Ms. Pringle!

Glad it's working for some people, and I agree, how is it really any worse than many of the alternatives? Some people we might meet at social events, bars or on Match.com may not be stable or suitable. Same thing as online.
My nephew met his wife on Everquest. They have 2 kids now. He moved halfway across the country to marry her.
My mother met a wonderful man at age 80 on Match.com. Two years later, they are still going strong. Let's celebrate these new ways for people to connect!

I always enjoyed seeing commuters leave the newspaper on top of the trash bins in Grand Central and Penn Station so that others may take them.

I imagine no one leaves access to the New York Times online behind.

Nice article. As a filmmaker, I agree that the culture, and film in particular, did not explode into a radical feminist paradise of a huge number of the (cultural, visual, narrative) films I would have like to have seen follow on the heels of Thelma and Louise. But -- the world has continued to change, and films continue to be made, both locally and globally, that explore the questions and ideas that Callie Courie asked in her screenplay Thelma and Louise. This season, at New Directors/New Films, you could have seen Cairo 678, about three women, in Cairo, who stand up against sexual harassment. They fight back: both physically, and legally, and win. It's the most feminist film I've seen in years, and it comes from an Arab country, (not the first place you think of as fomenting feminist cinema) and is directed by a guy! Or, at Sundance, you might have seen Gun Hill Road, about a young transgender woman coming of age, played by an actress who is a young transgender woman: also, at Sundance, you might have seen a film set in Iran about two female lovers, and what they have to do to survive in that society. All of those three films will have releases, by the way: so go see them! Thelma and Louise didn't change society, but it paved the way for screen images that will matter to current and future generations of filmmakers and most importantly, to movie-goers like you and me and all the young women and men coming out of school now. And that is, although not yet enough, still a kind of happy ending.

Hello America. These people are not citizens. They never wanted to be citizens and will never will be citizens.

Wake up people!

rik zak

Indefinite detention without trial is the policy of police states. There is not enough evidence that will hold up in court against the vast majority of prisoners at Guantanamo, so we have simply decided to hold them indefinitely.

It's extremely painful for me to think of our country disgraced in this way. And this inflammatory slide show on your paper's website only seems to be trying to justify this terrible miscarriage of justice. Shame on you.
